video.title: Snake Game Python Tutorial
video.description:
Learn to code a snake game using Python and Pygame.

This is suited for intermediate level programmers with some experience but anyone is welcome to follow along.

If you are unsure about how to install/download pygame checkout this link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AdUZArA-kZw

Download the code: https://pastebin.com/embed_js/jB6k06hG

Tutorial from Tech With Tim.
Check out Tim's channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC4JX40jDee_tINbkjycV4Sg

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: re:Union
topLevelComment.text:
some quick styling tips for other learners:
1. you dont need to inherit from the object class unless you are aiming for python2 compatibility (you probably aren't)
2. classes should start with a capital letter
3. variables and function should follow snake_casing with words seperated by _ and all lower case

this is only stylistic but conventions are not a bad thing to learn if you are going to do a lot of programming in one language

topLevelComment.author: David Hearn
topLevelComment.text:
34:24: When I tried to run it, the snake would move toward the right, but as soon as I hit an arrow key, it displays this error:

self.turns[self.head.pos[:]] = [self.dirnx, self.dirny]
TypeError: 'tuple' object does not support item assignment

I gained an understanding of most of the tutorial by giving verbose, meaningful names to all of the variables, but that error seems to be a show-stopper.

replies.author: Adnan
replies.text: Turns out the mistake was turns = [] which is meant to define arrays. Turns has to be defined as a dictionary using {} brackets.

replies.author: Adnan
replies.text: Have you found the reason why this error appears?

topLevelComment.author: WGX 13579
topLevelComment.text:
line 195 : for x in range(len(s.body)):
This line is unnecessary since the only possible case is for the snake's head to be collision with the snake's body. 

Replace the next line with : if s.body[0].pos in list(map(lambda z:z.pos,s.body[1:])): 



This will give the same result.

topLevelComment.author: ¥MoritzPainz¥
topLevelComment.text:
In the code the class snake is defined as follows:


class snake(object):
    body = []
    turns = {}

    def __init__(self, color, pos):
        self.color = color 
        self.head = cube(pos)
        self.body.append(self.head)
        self.dirnx = 0
        self.dirny = 1




Iam wondering why the bode list and the turns string is not written in the __init__() (constructor) function. when to put somthing in the __init__() function and when to put it 'directly in to the class'?


Thank you very much guys!

replies.author: OtakuLeveledUp
replies.text:
Pygame works like a constant loop. Once you load in the pictures and set the hit boxes every frame/loop it is waiting for a button to be pressed. When pressed the x or y axis is updated of the snake which moves the image a bit each time and then refreshes the page. 
Simple once you get it

replies.author: Albin Green
replies.text: You need to install pygame. In a terminal (type cmd in your windows search bar or equivalent on a linux distro), type "python3 -m pip install -U pygame --user". If you're running an older version of python, type "python" instead of "python3". Best regards :)

topLevelComment.author: Nátán Frank
topLevelComment.text:
In the snake's move() function you loop through the pressed keys but it doesn't make sense nor has any effect since you are checking only the values belonging to  K_UP, K_DOWN, K_LEFT and K_RIGHT in the dictionary, but they don't change in the loop.
So I guess you can just get rid of that loop and check the conditions just once.

topLevelComment.author: Final Fantasy
topLevelComment.text:
My thoughts regarding the first 3 minutes:
- Class names start with lowercase letters.
- method name words separated with underscore but not always. e.g.  message_box()  and randomSnack()
- defined snake object like;   s = snake()   instead of   snake = Snake().   s does not make any sense here.
I don't care if this code works or not but this is a horrible way of coding.
